awd_titl_txt: Scalable Multilevel Multicell Power Architectures Leveraging Cost Effective GaN Power IC Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Wide bandgap semiconductors such as silicon carbide and gallium nitride are poised to revolutionize the next generation of power electronics and electricity infrastructures. Their penetration into the market, however, is hindered by two major barriers: cost and reliability.  The objective of this project is to explore new multilevel power conversion architectures leveraging cost-competitive gallium nitride power integrated circuits, and establish a viable technological pathway for breaking through these cost and reliability barriers. The demand for electricity is expected to increase significantly with further electrification of the world driven by renewable energy usage, electrification of transportation, expansion of efficient electrical heating and cooling, expansion of information traffic, increased industrial motor usage, and new smart grid development. By 2030, an estimated 80% of all U.S. electricity is expected to flow through power electronics. Advanced wide bandgap power electronics will play a critical role in all phases of the electricity life cycle including generation, distribution and consumption, and have the potential to improve electricity efficiency by 10-25%. With the proposed advanced converter topologies, it is possible to realize efficiency gains by facilitating higher levels of adoption for cost-effective gallium nitride semiconductors in applications of power supplies, electric vehicles, data centers, solar inverters, power conditioners, electric motor drives, and wind power systems. 

The objective of this project is to explore scalable multilevel multicell power conversion architectures to extend the power rating of gallium nitride power converters to the range of 100 kW, fully utilizing low-voltage (40-300V), cost-competitive, reliability-proven, commercially available gallium nitride transistors. This is distinctly different from the mainstream approach on developing wide bandgap power converters using high-voltage (>1200V) semiconductor devices, which continue to face cost and reliability challenges. The new approach, originally developed for megawatt industrial applications, if adapted properly for the proposed lower power levels, will offer the same benefits of increased power rating and efficiency, reduced harmonic distortion, electro-magnetic interference, and improved redundancy and reliability, in addition to cost and size reduction.  These objectives will be met through the combination of (1) advanced architectures and topologies, (2) new control strategies and modulation techniques, (3) gallium nitride power IC building blocks and integrated gate driver, and 4) integration and scalability allowing for a broader range of power applications. The research plan includes major research components in the areas of power converter topologies, design, modeling, prototyping, and testing of the power converters; control and modulation techniques; development of gallium nitride device integration and converter scalability strategies; and evaluation and benchmarking against existing solutions.

por.por_cntn:
Power electronics are an integral, though little recognized, part of everyday life. With diverse applications and industries that range from hybrid and electric vehicles, high efficiency heating ventilation and cooling (HVAC), home appliances, to grid interfaces for solar and wind power. The reliability and fault tolerance of power electronics is critical for maintaining our health, safety, comfort, and economic well-being.

 

This project focused on multi-level converters with the goal of improving reliability and fault tolerance. Multi-level converters have a number of output voltage levels greater than two. Presently, the most common applications of multi-level converters are high power and medium voltages. A multi-level converter structure allows the overall voltage rating of the converter to exceed the voltage rating of the power semiconductor switches or to reduce the switching losses in the high voltage rated power semiconductors while maintaining an acceptable equivalent output switching frequency. Increasingly, multi-level converters are also being used at lower power and voltage levels where an output waveform with low distortion is needed. The multiple voltage output levels allow the filtering to be minimized.

 

To obtain the multiple output voltage levels and higher overall operating voltages additional power semiconductor switches are used in multi-level converters. The additional power semiconductor switches also require additional gate drive and other ancillary components. The addition of these components could reduce the reliability of the converter. For critical applications the converter would ideally still deliver power even if there is a fault. The main outcome of this project was the development of techniques to detect open circuit faults in the power semiconductors of multi-level converters, localize the fault, and potentially bypass the fault to continue delivering power to the load albeit perhaps with a small compromise in performance. A particular challenge was to detect and localize the fault from just terminal voltage and current measurements. No additional sensors were added internally to the multi-level converter.

Multiple open circuit fault detection, localization, and mitigation techniques were developed for the family of flying capacitor multi-level converters. The techniques are based on comparing the predicted output terminal voltage with the measured one. Open circuit faults can be detected in only a few pulse width modulation cycles. In addition, using the same terminal voltage and current measurement techniques for the estimation of internal capacitor voltages without sensors were also developed. The proposed techniques were verified experimentally in multiple multi-level converter prototypes.

Another outcome of this project was the development of hybrid fractional power processing inverters. A low switching frequency higher power silicon inverter is used in parallel with a fast switching frequency lower power wide bandgap inverter. The total cost and efficiency of the proposed hybrid fractional power processing system is lower than a fully wide bandgap or silicon inverter of equivalent performance.

The fault detection, fault localization, fault mitigation, and hybrid fractional power processing technologies developed as part of this NSF award will help to speed the electrification of numerous industries and applications.
